utterances: And this is the way this is seen as there's goals to increase this in the future, right?
Well, yeah, the demand is so high that they have set goals of more and more pilots, we should say drone pilots, over the next several years.

But right - one of the significant milestones happened the last six months, late last year and then again early this year, with a graduation of pilots who are drone pilots but who have never seen, essentially, the inside of a cockpit ever.
Wow.
And so that, for the Air Force, was a significant thing.
That's right - and because everything's being held up in the Senate.
And that's really where the focus...
Yeah, I know.
Absolutely.
I mean, they weren't visible.
I mean, I went down to Nabatiyeh, which is a very dicey road.
I went down there from Beirut - and I did a lot of thinking about it before I went down there - and when I got there I mean it was deserted.
But there were more people there than one would suppose, but they were underground.
They were in their shelters and their cellars and that sort of thing, and they're just emerging after a lot of weeks down there.
But at best, I would say if you take Nabatiyeh as exemplary, there's probably 5,000 people there.
Now there's 25,000 people.

Now there's an estimated probably - according to the U.N., and I think they've done a pretty good job of estimating this - there's about 10,000 homes in south Beirut and south Lebanon that are not habitable.
And for those folks, now it's tough - it's a tough road.
They'll basically go into neighbors' homes, family's homes, but they'll stay in close proximity to their land.
These are - most of these folks down in south Lebanon, except for those on the coast, most of them are farmers and the draw to the land was something that I think the U.N.
and NGOs like Mercy Corps underestimated.
We thought that they would be a little more tentative, a little more cautious in going back home.
Now it's different for the folks in south Beirut.
And as you know, about half the displaced people came from south Beirut.
And they're a little more tentative, they're staying up a couple of hours maximum in the hills to the east and they're sending their heads of household down south.
Now these are mostly apartments.
They're not agricultural folks.
They're small retailers and that sort of stuff.
So we still have displaced, mostly from south Beirut, and those people will go back probably over the next week or two.
But no doubt it's a rush - it's a rush to get home.

And we're real happy, non-governmental organizations like Mercy Corps, because it seems like despite the popular skepticism about the durability of this cease-fire they believe enough in it that they're going home.
Well, David Holdridge, thanks very much.
We appreciate it, and get some sleep.
I will.
Thanks a lot.
David Holdridge is the Middle East program director of Mercy Corps, which is an international relief and development agency.
We spoke with him a couple of weeks ago when the situation - when organizations like his were not so happy.
He joined us today from his home in Beirut
From NPR News, this is WEEKEND EDITION.
I'm Liane Hansen.
And these were some of the voices in the news this past week.

Kirk) Scotty.

President GEORGE W.
BUSH: I look forward to the Senate voting to confirm Judge John Roberts as the 109th justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
Judge JOHN G.
ROBERTS (Supreme Court Nominee): I always got a lump in my throat whenever I walked up those marble steps to argue a case before the court, and I don't think it was just from the nerves.
I am very grateful for the confidence the president has shown in nominating me, and I look forward to the next step in the process before the United States Senate.

We have to ensure the Supreme Court remains a protector of all Americans' rights and liberties from government intrusion and that the Supreme Court understands the role of Congress in passing legislation to protect ordinary Americans from special-interest abuses.
No one is entitled to a free pass to a lifetime appointment to the Supreme Court.
I didn't see smoke.
I could just smell smoke.
And as we pulled into Warren Street, we just got off the train and tried to exit out of it, and like, people were panicking and, like, screaming and just--it was just lots of confusion.
We react calmly and continue with our lives, and that's what I intend to do and I'm sure people will do the same.
The policeman nearest to me had the black automatic pistol in his left hand.
He held it down to the guy and unloaded five shots into him.
I've never seen anything like it in my life, really.
It's--I saw them kill a man.
At first, I didn't even think it was a bomb.
I just thought it was some sort of explosion or some sort of crash.
All the windows are broken, and when I seen that, I knew that something severe must have happened.
For nearly a century, New Yorkers waited and waited for a subway extension along Second Avenue on Manhattan's east side.
Yesterday, this urban legend came true.
From member station WNYC in New York, Steven Nessen reports.
(Cheering).
New Yorkers don't usually cheer when a subway leaves the station, but this wasn't just any subway or any old station.
To understand why hundreds came out New Year's Day to ride a train, you have to go back to the 1920s.
That's when the idea for a subway line on Second Avenue was first floated, but then the Depression hit.
The idea was revived again in the 1950s as a replacement for the elevated trains.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #1: But the old steel skeleton outlived its usefulness.
Passengers dwindled, and so the El is being torn down.
But city planner Robert Moses decided to spend money building expressways instead.
In 1968, for the first time, the city got federal funding to build a subway on Second Avenue.
It was expected to cost $220 million.
The TV show ""Mad Men"" even worked in a reference to the plan that year.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""MAD MEN"")
So you blame Congress, not the president.
The thing is that these are this is the thing the Air Force is most needed for right now.
So culturally, it's just difficult because everybody, you know, Air Force officers, pilots, join to kind of live this dream of flying off, you know, into the sunset, Billy Mitchell, these kinds.
But the reality is that they're needed in a different way.
So they've really had to come to terms with that.
Or they're going to have to change their recruiting techniques now, go hit up MIT a little more, maybe.
Well, I mean, it's true.
The kind of image of the perfect Air Force officer, you know, the ideal is a different one.

It's a guy who in my case, where I visited, at Creech Air Force Base outside of Las Vegas, and there's several of these around the country, you know, they operate inside trailers, and they've got a dozen monitors in front of them, and they're chatting with people on IM, other operators around the world and in the war zone.
But that's the for now, that is the future of the Air Force.

I would do a quick likening it to kind of a personal issue is journalists who worked online for years were always kind of seen as maybe not as important as the ones who got their work in print, if we talk about just newspaper reporters.
Mm-hmm.
It's really turned on its head now for us.
That's the future.
And people who work and are able to embrace the online world, you know, are kind of maybe seeing in the future for where it's going to go.
And I think but it doesn't feel right, and I think it's the same thing for the Air Force.
So there's some internal tensions there, some kind of between the do you call them pilots, drone pilots, drone jocks?
What are they called?
Yeah, I mean, drone jocks.
I think some people say, you know, joystick boys.
You know, they're felt or perceived to be a leper colony within the Air Force, but that is that perception is beginning to diminish.
Now, we're going to hear from listeners in just a second, but I want to ask if you spoke with some of these drone jocks, pilots.
What did they say about it?
It just must be such a disconnect, you know, to have a kind of a nine-to-five existence in America while your job really is in the combat zone over in, you know, the Middle East.
What do they say about that?
It's a really fascinating phenomenon, and I did get a chance to spend some time with them and seeing what they do.
You know, they literally are their head is completely in the war for 10- to 12-hour shifts, and then they go home, maybe pick up a gallon of milk and a video on the way home and see their kids.

These guys who work really hard and who have in effect been prevented from moving on to other assignments within the Air Force because of the demand are probably perceived a little bit unfairly by folks within the military who do work in the battle on the battlefield.
I mean, it's hard work.
It's very stressful for them, even though they get to go see their families at night.
They really have to turn it off, turn it on, turn it off.
Whereas somebody who is obviously deployed for a year, they can have a different dynamic.
Much more separation, right.
Well, there's much more separation, but they kind of they're all in for the whole time.
These guys have to, as I say, turn it off each day.
Let's hear from a veteran pilot.
Roger(ph) is in San Francisco, and he's on the line.
Hi, Roger.
Yes, I am a veteran Marine, but I'm a private pilot.
I never flew in the Marines.
